trial_identification.studytitle: Reducing brain injury in cardiac surgery
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Dual vent circuit cardiopulmonary bypass to reduce ischemic brain injury in cardiac surgery.

conditions.healthcondition: Elective cardiac valve repair or repair in the left heart and brain injury.

interventions.interventions: Randomised controlled participant and assessor blinded study of an investigational dual vent circuit cardiopulmonary bypass technique in elective open heart surgery patients. Pre-operative and up to 6 weeks post-operative clinical assessments and magnetic resonance imaging studies performed.
interventions.comparator: Conventional cardiopulmonary bypass in elective open heart surgery patients.

primaryOutcome.outcome: New ischemic lesions on post-operative magnetic resonance imaging studies.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Clinical outcome of death, coma, stroke, transient ischemic attack, post-operative encephalopathy and cognitive impairment.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Able to give informed consent; neurologically independent; requiring elective cardiac valve replacement or repair in the left heart; able to undergo magnetic resonance imaging.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Concomitant medical conditions making followup over 6 weeks unlikely; hemodynamically unstable; frequent cardiac arrhythmias; mobile atherosclerotic plaque in the aortic arch; overt congestive heart failure.

trial_design.sequence: Computer generated random allocation in blocks.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Park Rd, Grafton Auckland 1001 New Zealand

fundingsource.fundingaddress: 66 Grafton Rd, Grafton 1010 Auckland New Zealand

fundingsource.fundingname: National Heart Foundation of New Zealand
fundingsource.fundingaddress: PO Box 17160. Greenlane Auckland 1546 New Zealand

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The primary purpose of the study is to investigate whether a newly developed cardiopulmonary (heart) bypass technique, reduces brain injury as a complication of the surgery, compared with conventional cardiopulmonary bypass techniques.
ethicsAndSummary.publication:
Barber PA, Hach S, Tippett LJ, Ross L, Merry AF, Milsom P. Cerebral ischemic lesions on diffusion-weighted imaging are associated with neurocognitive decline after cardiac surgery. Stroke. 2008;39(5):1427-33.
Barber PA, Tippett LJ, Merry AF, Hach S, Frampton C, Milsom P. Post-operative ischemia and cognitive impairment in cardiac surgery patients. Ann Thoracic Surgery. 2009;87(2):673-4.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Northern X Health and Disabilities Ethics Committee
